Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Participant Support for COMBINE 2015 to be held in Salt Lake City, UT on October 12-16, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Standards for data exchange are critical to the development of any field. They enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably, apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. This is a project to support a workshop on this topic in October, 2015 to be held in Salt Lake City, Utah. The meeting is organized by the COmputational MOdeling in BIology NEtwork (COMBINE), which was created in 2010 to organize standardization efforts for systems biology. The request if for participant costs to enable students and junior scientist attend the meeting. They will learn will learn valuable lessons in the importance of research and tool standardization and the impact of a community-wide effort. This effort is essential for areas of systems and synthetic biology and translational research where to be seamless.

The meetings will specifically explore data exchange standards for biology to enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably, apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. The discussion will center, among others, on the systems biology markup language (SBML) for mathematical modeling, the biological pathways exchange language (BioPaX) for describing pathways, the systems biology graphical notation (SBGN) for visual representations, and the synthetic biology open language(SBOL) for describing biological designs. While synthetic biology data exchange has many unique requirements, there are also many overlapping goals such as the need to construct mathematical models, describe pathways, and provide visual representations. Therefore, it is highly beneficial to join these efforts, such that, the synthetic biology community can leverage existing standards enabling the sharing of tools and other infrastructure. Likewise, the other communities will benefit from renewed discussions around data exchange and synthetic biology's unique process of forward engineering living systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided registration support for twenty-eight students, postdoctoral fellows, junior researchers, and members of under-represented groups to attend COMBINE Forum in Salt Lake City, Utah in October 2016 (http://co.mbine.org/events/COMBINE_2015).  This event is organized annually by the Computational Modeling in Biology Network (COMBINE).  The goal of this event is to promote the development of the standards and supporting infrastructure for systems and synthetic biology, as well as, interoperability between these standards.  The primary COMBINE standards are the systems biology markup language (SBML), systems biology graphical notation (SBGN), simulation experiment description markup language (SED-ML), the biological pathway (BioPAX) description language, the cell markup language (CellML), and the synthetic biology open language (SBOL). This was the first COMBINE Forum in which SBOL participated.

At COMBINE, the first day is a seminar day composed of invited talks.  In particular, we had four sessions (Modeling, Visualization, Neuroscience, and Synthetic Biology).  Each session included one speaker from the COMBINE standards community and one practitioner.  The following four days were composed of contributed talks in the morning, and breakout discussion sections in the afternoon with posters during the breaks.  Most supported students presented either a talk or a poster. The goal of the breakout sessions is to consider improvements for the COMBINE data standards, and all of the supported students participated in these discussions.  While many of the breakouts focused on individual standards, there were some that involved multiple standards.  For example, the SBML and SED-ML communities discussed improvements for whole-cell modeling, while the SBOL Visual and SBGN communities discussed integration of their standards.

This grant was instrumental to the success of this meeting.  Many of the people working on standard development are students and postdocs that either volunteer their time or have limited resources for travel. Without this grant, it would have been prohibitively expensive for many of the participants to attend.  This was a great experience for the students and postdocs enabling them to share their work and interact with the larger community, and contribute to the next versions of these standards.
